summary: Townspeople fight back when a swarm of birds causes bloody mayhem.

reviews.content: This is an amazing film! The opening shots of the California coast are awesome, and you can easily understand what the characters are saying most of the time. Plus, the bird attacks are super intense! I especially love how quickly characters die (especially Ramsey screw that guy). And let's not even begin to talk about the sex scenes. Absolute art I tell ya. The special effects might not be top-notch, but they still get the job done. I'd totally recommend it if you're into romantic-horror movies.

The birds were so realistic, made the whole movie a 10/10. The characters were really thought out and had wonderful development. The actors slayed their roles, they embodied their characters. The chemistry between the cast was amaizng, no awkward moments. They felt like a real found family. A must see!
A cultural reset. Don't expect a good movie, but expect a great time (watch with friends).

Birdemic: Shock and Terror, where to begin. This film is on a whole new level.  No one has ever attempted something so risky before, but the results are phenomenal.  Director James Nguyen mastered the art of a romantic horror movie.  I cried, I screamed, I hid under the covers, but I couldn't look away.  I have never seen something so beautiful in my life.  In this review I will break down every aspect of this barrier breaking film, so please join me on this journey through Birdemic: Shock and Terror.
Let's start with the main part of every film, the acting.  It is the best acting I have ever seen in any film.  Rod (played by Alan Bagh) and Nathalie (Whitney Moore) had a real love connection in this film.  After the film ended I wiped the tears from my eyes and had to know if these two actors were married.  I was heartbroken when I found out they weren't truly together in real life.  They were perfect for each other and I was angry that the birds had to attack them and ruin these two who showed true emotions for one another.  I cannot even begin to fathom how much practice and skill all of the people in this film had.  They knew every line.  They spoke with confidence and pride.  The phone scene for example, these actors showed how much they were interested in each other's lives.  You could learn a thing or two from Rod and Nathalie's relationship.  And the basketball scene too.  The NBA better get to Rod before he gets too involved in acting because he has some great skills on the court.  But emotions were another big part of this movie.  (!SPOILER ALERT!) When Becky (Catherine Batcha) was killed by an eagle I collapsed onto the floor.  I felt the world crumbling down around me.  I felt like I knew Becky on a personal level and it was like one of my closest friends getting killed by an eagle.  But it doesn't end there.  The emotion demonstrated by Ramsey (Adam Sessa) was overwhelming.  I had to pause the film and I was apologizing to Ramsey.  I cried out, "Why?  Why did they have to take Becky away from Ramsey?  I am so sorry Ramsey!  I wish I could be there with you!"  And in a way I did feel like I was there with him.  I can't make you watch this film, but if you saw any number of great Oscar winning movies you must see this.  I thought I knew what good acting was until I saw Birdemic: Shock and Terror.
Let's move on to the next category, the sound and editing.  I don't know what camera they used in Birdemic: Shock and Terror, but I wish I did.  I know that the quality wasn't too great, but if you watch Birdemic: Shock and Terror and then watch another movie that came out in 2010 you will know what I mean when I say, the way they filmed this revolutionized the whole film industry.  The film moves so smoothly.  Like a knife cutting through warm butter.  It almost appears as if the whole film was taken in one long shot.  Amazing.  The sound was also absolutely incredible.  Every word these amazing actors and actresses spoke was crystal clear.  This amazing audio adds to the effect of this film and its greatness.  And the music.  How could I ever explain to you the music in this film?  I can't.  You must listen to its soundtrack to know what I mean.  My favorite song from this movie was sung by the Nightclub Singer (Damien Carter).  This song is hands down my all-time favorite song ever.  And with Rod and Nathalie dancing to it made it even better.  They knew some great moves and demonstrated them perfectly in this film.
Onto the next category, the plot.  Never have I been so intrigued with a plot.  It had so many twists and turns in this movie.  And much like the filming it went so smoothly.  Everything the characters did made total sense.  I really made a lot of connections with the real world because of this plot.  I think it is amazing how a film, like this one, can transport you to a whole new reality.  Many great films have plot holes, or they lag at some point.  This movie had neither.  And director James Nguyen brought attention to the global warming crisis.  If we don't start using hybrid cars or solar panels birds will soon start flying into the streets exploding on impact.  This film isn't only a work of art, it is also a warning.  Do you want your eyes to be eaten out by a CGI bird?  I think not, so we need to change, and this film taught me that.  The theme of this movie was much deeper.  It hit me right in the heart.  The theme of course being, if birds ever attack get a lot of gas before the gas prices go up to $100.00 a gallon.  In the end I learned that we need to clean up our Earth or prepare for a full blown Birdemic.  We would be filled with shock and terror.
Now the final point in my review, the special effects.  While watching this film I was generally concerned for the safety of these actors (but luckily they had totally real guns and coat hangers).  I thought the birds were real this entire movie.  It wasn't until after the movie when I did some research that I found out the birds were (!SPOILER ALERT!) FAKE!  That's right all you moviegoers, the birds you saw in Birdemic: Shock and Terror were all fake.  They were just animated.  I had to watch Birdemic: Shock and Terror a second time because I couldn't believe they were animated birds.  Can you believe that they were fake?  I sure can't.  I think that is one thing they are lying about.  They just looked too realistic.  I mean the sounds alone made me think there were birds flying around my own home! It was crazy.  Speaking of sounds I want to warn you: you do NOT need to call the police when you hear them fire their guns in Birdemic: Shock and Terror.  I will repeat myself: you do NOT need to call the police when you hear them fire their guns in Birdemic: Shock and Terror.  When I heard the first gun shot I hid behind my coach thinking someone was firing at me.  I was about to call the police when I realized that it was only more special effects.  My mind was blown.  I couldn't believe it.  
When the credits started rolling at the end of Birdemic: Shock and Terror I stood up and started clapping.  Tears were streaming down my face.  I couldn't believe it was over.  James Nguyen never ever received the credit he deserved for this revolutionary film.  I tell you if you haven't seen this movie you NEED TO.  Children in schools should be required to watch this film because it is part of our history and soon to be part of our future if we don't change our ways.  I would like to say one thing to all the people mocking this movie, how dare you?  How dare you mock this masterpiece?  Could you do better?  NO.  YOU COULD NOT.  Any movie made after Birdemic: Shock and Terror is just trying to achieve something they will never be able to achieve because Birdemic: Shock and Terror has already claimed it.  Please watch this movie, it has changed me, and it will change you.  I urge you to also bring a box of tissues with you wherever you go to see this movie.  You'll need them.  Thank You.

Just being a stupid movie about people fighting poorly composited CGI bird sprites that are apparently made of explodium would've sufficed. But nope, they just had to have the most abysmal production values ever seen in a movie. From piss-poor cinematography to terrible audio syncing as well as acting that even Tommy Wiseau would cringe at coupled with tons of borderline hilarious "angst? what angst?" with one exception, Birdemic lives up to its subtitle, all right but not in the way the filmmakers were expecting.

Supposedly a tribute to Hitchcock's classic, nothing could have fallen shorter of its mark. Birds don't even appear until 20 minutes into the movie, and the main conflict doesn't even begin until halfway through its 90 minute runtime (it will feel longer). The misfired environmental message is only accentuated by accidentally hilarious editing, earsplitting sound design, wooden acting, worst of the worst special effects, and wandering plot. Birdemic takes so-bad-its-good movies into the 21st century.

I'll give this movie some credit: I never thought an actual production team could manage to absolutely ruin every single aspect of a movie. The script, the plot, the acting, the props, the visual effects, the compositing, the video editing, the sound design, the cinematography, and the lighting are all so mind-bogglingly awful that it's hard to imagine a team of adults actually managing to craft such a morbid testament to filmmaking incompetence. It's so utterly terrible that it is, in fact, worth the watch. It's so horrifically bad that it's come full circle and earned a place in the hearts of cult fans worldwide. 

It's a masterpiece, but not in the way that would earn it a 10/10 on Rotten Tomatoes.

BIRDEMIC: The Shock and Terror is one of the finest examples of modern art and film ever exhibited. Combining incredibly stale young actors with a riveting and thrilling plot, the film's commentary on climate change and an inevitable battle for human survival against wild birds is not only touching, but profound and important. Topping it all of with breathtaking CGI effects, Birdemic is easily one of the best movies to come out in the past 20 years.

Birdemic features a bad script filled with some of the worst dialog in film and and an awkward obsession with the characters personal lives and their views on global warming. The visual effects are basically three different animations green screened into shots. They look laughably fake. Bridemic is nearly the worst film ever made. I would input a zero star rating if that was possible. 3/100

Pointless, plotless and painfully dull, James Nguyen's DIY thriller is a bird-brained disaster. Sure, the tacky visual effects make for the odd laugh, but this is by no means a good bad movie; it's an irredeemable attack on the senses.
Birdemic is literally a catalogue of awkward conversations, screechy bird noises and random encounters with oddball environmentalists, each louder and uglier than the last. One minute the characters are preaching green, the next they're pointing toy guns at seemingly stationary, crudely animated birds which, let's face it, doesn't stay funny for long.
Birdemic is aimless, conflict-less and utterly confused, and it brings a whole new meaning to amateur filmmaking. Be sure to keep a finger on your volume control.

Birdemic is awful, though I pretty much knew that going into it. I also knew that it has a sort of reputation as another one of those awful films that's fascinating to pick at and learn from as a film that gets everything wrong. While some may choose to see it that way, I don't really. I've seen films like Troll 2 and The Room where they're so awful that get so much wrong, but are entertaining to pick at and are so bizarre that they're beautiful messes. Birdemic isn't quite like that for me, it's a film that should be seen once because its technically appalling in camera work, sound design, and of course visual effects, and well... just everything including a completely unfocused story that goes nowhere. But Birdemic is a boring specimen, and not every collossal failure in filmmaking necessarily makes it into the Hall Of Masterfully Awful Films. 

Birdemic is one to watch if you need that fix on watching something that reminds you of how low filmmaking can dip, and like any film in its level, its usually fun to watch again as long as you're showing to a friend who has no idea what they're getting into! It's also amazing just to know that this shit really gets made by people who are serious about what they were making, but I personally find this one was just dull and where its awfullness only escalated to a certain point and kept recycling it till everything awful there was to be fascinated with just becomes... less entertaining. It's not like other terrible films with a following that have a lot to come back to. Birdemic is easily swallowed in once, and you got what you need. If I'm ever going to show friends a film that's notoriously bad and must be seen to believed, I can see myself resorting to other more interesting specimens than Birdemic. Otherwise, dive into some amusing bad but dull amateur filmmaking at your own risk, but its always better with a friend!

For what it is, it's entertaining for all the wrong reasons. I like movies like this that think they're being serious when they're clearly far from it. (See "The Room"). An absolute masterpiece. You have never seen anything like this before, I can guarantee it. Unbelievable in every sense of the word. I really don't know where to even start with it.

First, the acting is just amazing. Honestly, it makes the cast of 'Troll 2' look like Robert Redford, Dustin Hoffman and Daniel Day Lewis. Alan Bagh turns in what is without a doubt the best/worst performance of all time, and I say that with no reservations. Fortunately for everyone's enjoyment, every other cast member is equally horrific. An excellent twist of casting events is detailed on the back of the DVD, exclaiming 'Featuring a special appearance by Tippi Heddrin!!' I'm seriously not shitting you, this 'special appearance' is footage of her on the TV in the background of a scene. 

Another thing is, of course, the special effects. To call them 'special effects' is actually disrespectful to special effects, because in place of effects are GIFs. It is so unreal that it really makes you question the reality we live in. 

The direction and editing (particularly the sound editing) are other major points. It is simply a masterpiece of technical execution. The fact that this took Nguyen 4 years to produce this is mind-numbing. It seriously should have taken perhaps 4 weeks.

All of the horrible acting, execution and visual effects aside, the dialogue and story are what sell it. So may incredible moments... The dance scene at the bar, the boardroom scene, the hippie in the woods scene, the coat-hanger scene, and a plethora of others combine for a most memorable viewing experience. The ridiculously heavy handed message regarding global warming has done more harm than good for the cause I'm sure.

There is no way I can properly put into perspective the incredible horrificness of this movie. It is simply incredible. Incredible. I can not wait for 'Birdemic 2' in motherfucking 3D.

The Room still has this beat, but that doesn't mean Birdemic: Shock and Terror isn't knocking on its door, saying, "Hi, neighbor!" James Nguyen may not have accomplished much, other than achieving cult-status that accompanies films like these, but if he has accomplished anything, it's making Ed Wood seem legit.

There are a hundred times during the course of "Birdemic" that I wondered about the mental status of writer/director James Nguyen, but the aspect of the film that I questioned the most was what his intentions were by making it. Did he plan on making a legendarily horrible film that would live on for eternity on the midnight circuit or was he actually trying to make a good film?

Regardless of what he thought he was doing, he has managed to make one of the best bad films of all time, a film that is so inept in every single conceivable way that writing a review seems almost pointless. Nguyen has no idea how people talk, even in conventional settings such as talking with your mother on the phone or ordering from a restaurant. Star Alan Bagh seems to have trouble walking naturally in certain scenes.

The film pushes a green agenda but never really offers a convincing explanation for the bird attacks, and they end as mysteriously as they began. The film spends a full forty-five minutes on these character's mundane lives before the animals even attack, and when they finally do, it's some of the worst special effects I've ever seen. The computer generated birds hover without flapping their wings and make gull sounds when they are clearly eagles. The dialogue is curiously stilted and awkward, the actors seem to have no idea when scenes begin and end and the sound drops out almost continuously throughout the picture. But you'll laugh, loud and often and because of that, the legacy of "Birdemic" will always be secure. And to think, some filmmakers have to actually try to achieve that success.

James Nguyen has constructed the worst piece of cinema in history, and the final product shows that he has never been to film school, never studied films or how to make them for that matter, and it became a cluster F$#K of a movie, filled with cheap gags, the worst visuals on the face of the earth, stomach turning sound design, horrendous editing, and direction that makes absolutely no sense. With takes being reused over and over again and effects that could have been created by a kid in grade school learning after effects, "Birdemic" is THE WORST film I have ever seen and will ever see. The funny thing is, I hoped the entire time, that this film was a joke, but it is surely not. Let's just say that you must be extremely bored if you take the time to watch this thing.

This film not only exceeds expectations as a cult classic remake of Arnold Hitchcock's famed movie film in theatres, Le Birds Extreme, but sets new grounds for acting, romance, thrills, terror shocks and especially special effects. The acting from well-known actors such as Zoya Bikkibokkoocoggidubbinuwwubnus and Billy 'You're-gonna-sell-me-some-gas" Man (as well as a cameo as Daniel Day-Lewis at Nat's mom) excels in almost every respect. The romance rivals that of Passion of the Christ 3: Passion Levels Critical, the thrills that of When Harry Met Sally 2: More Harry, More Sally and the horror that of the hit 1990 horror classic Big Momma's House 3, Like Father Like Son. The issues dealing with global warming are certainly subtle, yet completely valid, relevant and make sense to our modern world generation of people. To miss this underrated gem of motion picture would not only be a sin against America and what it stands for, but also to yourself. If you don't see this movie, we won't be angry, just disappointed. And remember, a day without Birdemic is a day wasted.

Hey, have you ever wanted to see a remake of The Birds? No? Well just imagine, take out the great direction and memorable characters and what do you get? You get Birdemic, a film that's so bad, you almost expect that it was made by birds.

The story surrounds a....do I even need to tell you? This is Manos bad. In fact, it may be even worse. But in all seriousness it's about a couple who visit Northern California on vacation. But guess what? There are birds attacking! Did they not see the title? That should have been their first warning.

The acting is just awful. How bad? Well, compared to Birdemic, Tommy Wiseau gets an Oscar. Oh yeah, I said that! The acting really is just awkward. People don't speak or walk like a normal person would.

The film in a nutshell is the modern B-Movie. But where other B-Movies could be liked due to the classic feel of 50s cheese, Birdemic comes off as dull. If they had set this in the 50s and thrown in some jokes, Birdemic could be called a comedy classic. Sadly, that's not the case.

I know this review is very brief, but there's just nothing more to say. It's an awful film with awful acting. So yeah, don't watch it. And, just think, they're working on a Birdemic 2. I'll be back with that when it comes around.

But if it's so bad, why does it get a 20% you may ask. Well I've got 2, and they don't have to do with the film itself, or at least not much. One is the Rifftrax on it which is great. The other reason is the great review from Phelous.

So, unless you have Rifftrax, don't watch Birdemic under any circumstance.

There are bad movies.  Then there are BAD movies.  I really don't know where to start.  First the story (if there is one) is about a software salesman and model who meet and later (much later) gets attacked by birds.  So much for originality.  Every aspect of this movie is bad.  Writing, acting, directing, editing, photography and special effects.  The movie never builds its premise and is filled with illogical and ridiculous scenes.  The Filmmakers failed to do research with anything remotely plausible.  It's an example of not having a clue on what they are doing.  "Bird" follows every pattern that hurts indie movies.  I respect their ambition but that's a poor substitute for talent.  At a budget of 10,000 I'm confused on where the money went.  If you love BAD movies, then be my guest.  My suggestion to the people who made this movie?  Go learn how to make a movie.

James Nguyen, the self-proclaimed "Master of Romantic Thrillers," delivers the most shocking(ly hilarious) creature feature of all-time! The residents of Half Moon Bay are inexplicably attacked by a pack of bloodthirsty birds, and it is up to a software salesman and his fashion model girlfriend to defeat the birds and save the day! BIRDEMIC is perfectly terrible in every way. Not since the days of Ed Wood has a filmmaker shown more inadequacy or more unachievable ambition. Had James Nguyen staged the entire production as an elaborate joke, he may have been considered a complete genius, but instead, he may now be regarded as one of the single worst directors of all-time. Nguyen puts together the most talentless cast since TROLL 2, and edits their atrocious dialog together using jarring cuts and awkward pauses. He holds on the most trivial shots for absurd amounts of time. What is worse, the audience is forced to suffer through forty-five minutes of painful character development before the birds finally arrive. But then... BIRDEMIC!

The onset of the attack is so sudden and unprovoked it simply boggles the mind. Most of the attacks consist of horrendous computerized birds flapping in place and squawking incessantly, while others simply dive bomb into cars and gas stations and explode for no reason at all. And then, when all seems lost, the birds just leave and its over. Now, this may sound ridiculous enough on paper, but seeing is believing. The action sequences are so unbelievably awful that they make for non-stop entertainment. The problem is that they are so repetitive and so incredibly unskilled that an hour and a half feels like an eternity.

BIRDEMIC single-handedly sets the green movement back twenty years with its failed ecological message, but in doing so, it establishes itself as the newest cult-classic of bad film. James Nguyen's complete incompetence allows for pure, unintentional humor that could never have been written better. As far as B-movies go, BIRDEMIC is a masterpiece. 

-Carl Manes

Birdemic is an awful, boring, low-budget, badly directed, atrociously edited, terribly written, horrifically paced, romance/thriller with awful special effects, wooden acting, the worst sound editing I have ever witnessed, and very few unintentionally hilarious moments. I decided to watch this with four friends; thinking that it would be laughably bad. We ended up talking throughout most of the movie, since it wasn't very entertaining. The movie was full of awful cuts, moronic edits, poorly delivered lines and ridiculous special effects, but it was rarely extremely entertaining or laughably bad. It was just bad. The male lead was awful, while the female lead was passable. They had absolutely no chemistry, but it was never really entertaining to watch them together. Yes, their delivery was wooden, and they read some of the worst dialogue I have ever heard, but it just wasn't enjoyable to watch. It was just dumb. The birds were all horribly animated, and there was even a scene where the birds just stayed in one place while the actors tried to fend them off. The scene was absolutely ridiculous; it wasn't exciting or scary, but it wasn't entertaining either. It was just dumb.
The movie also attempts to support environmentalism, but the attempt is heavy-handed and too poorly executed to be taken seriously. The main characters talk about "An Inconvenient Truth" while walking to their cars. They later randomly run into a scientist that explains that people, not the birds, are to blame for the birdemic.

There were a few entertaining moments, but overall, Birdemic isn't worth anyone's time. It's not particularly fun to watch, and it's just an awful movie. I'll give it a 2/10 simply because it did occasionally make me laugh due to the inane nonsense I saw on screen. This is not so bad it's good. This is just bad.

Quite simply, it is by far the worst movie I have ever seen. I had to watch it in increments, it was so bad. And I could forgive them if they were making it as a joke, but as anyone whose seen James Nguyen's interview, we know that it was actually intended to be taken seriously. Where to begin? The editing is absolutely horrendous; it's so bad that at times it looks like they were TRYING to make it seem and look uncomfortable and awkward. The acting is completely non-existant, and I found that my favorite actor in this movie was Nathalie's mother, who is in less than ten minutes of it, and I'm convinced she was told that she was simply being interviewed, and was unaware she was in an actual movie. The CGI (or should I say GIF) birds are by far the crown jewel of poor editing, they've only got one sound effect, they constantly loop that over, they look about as real as a three dollar bill, they explode on contact, and vomit acid. For absolutely no real reason. The story is not only unfocussed, it's confused. What is it? Is it a romantic comedy? Is it an end of the world thriller? Is it an environmental film? It's all over the place, has no rhyme or reason, no idea what it's doing, and unsurprisingly can do none of these things. The dialogue is forced, annoying, and completely un engaging. And perhaps most annoying of all is the director's decision to linger on scenes that have no meaning, no purpose, and no impact on either the story, or the audience. And most confusingly of all, the ending. WHAT HAPPENED THERE!? I have no idea what happened, and no idea why they took so long to role those blessed credits. I reserve special criticism for it's constant focus on global warming being the cause of the bird attack, when clearly this movie doesn't know what global warming is. The hippie who lives in the woods, and the doctor on the bridge are the worst offenders, not only shelling out contrived eco-friendly jargon, but having ABSOLUTELY no damn clue what any of it even means. This is a movie so completely terrible and entirely wrong, that it is the single greatest example of how NOT to do a movie.

Best worst film I have ever seen. I thought The Room or The Happening would be  the best worst film but oh no, those films are masterpieces compared to Birdemic. It is an absolute miracle of a film. Birdemic is so incompetent and so ungodly atrocious that it is an entity upon itself.  Horrendous effects, poor direction, wooden and bored acting, horrible editing, awkwardly and sloppily paced and ridiculously inconsistent throughout. The first part of the film is a boring as hell romance story, which takes up 45 MINUTES OF THE FILM. Holy crap. As I was watching this, I kept wondering if I was watching a different film altogether. Where are the killer birds? Why am I watching an extremely poorly acted romance film all of the sudden? Then the birds finally show up and are rendered in glorious Photoshop effects done by kindergarteners. From all the bad things I have mentioned about Birdemic and of course, fully deserves it, this film is hilarious and probably one of the funniest films I have ever seen. Watch it and be amazed at how ridiculously bad it is.

I know nothing about movie makeing but even on the level of just editing my lack of skills would do a better job.

Worst movie that you have to see. It's so bad, it's hilarious. I'll admit that I got pretty bored with the badness after awhile, and when the real crap hits the fan when the birds arrive, I was already uninvested in the movie. Some of the scenes are so incredibly drawn out that the hilarity from its horribleness wears away. Regardless, it is incredibly funny to watch, and you'll quote the movie with your friends for months. The stiff acting, awkward editing, uninspiring cinematography, nonexistent soundtracking, and MS Paint special effects make this movie possibly the best worst movie. Can't wait to see how the 3D sequel is gonna happen.

This movie was so bad, it was funny. Alan Bagh's acting is so monotone that it seems he's doing it on purpose. I will be one of the first in line for the sequel, but only because I want to see how badly they can screw it up.

This really seems like a total amateur high school level type filmmaking and its totally incompetent sincerity makes you feel sorry for the filmmakers. Get trashed and watch it and you'll laugh like crazy, but probably feel bad about it afterwards.

Marvel at the horrible audio throughout and the bad Manos acting. Hell' this must be the Manos the hands of fate for our time. And also witness the delusions of the director Nguyen who actually thinks this movie is a serious drama. Quick somebody check him into a mental hospital.

Spectacularly bad, right up there with the worst films ever made. But, there's fun to be had (admittedly, by mocking the film with your friends).

A hilariously bad movie that is only worth watching to get a laugh.

I did it.  Watched the whole movie from beginning to end.  Never stopped laughing or simply being in complete amazement at how unbelievably bad a movie can be made.  I can't even begin to put this thing into words!  Also, Whitney Moore :*

This might be the worst movie I have seen since the room. Unlike The Room, the production is amateur night. The sound cuts out a lot. The editing is beyond choppy. I can't tell if the movie is out of focus or if it's burry for being in low definition. The first 12 minutes of the movie is the protagonist driving, then walking to some random restaurant. Someone forgot to tell the actors that they should act. 

Nearly 30 minutes in I am still waiting for the Birdemic to hit. All I've seen is driving, awkard conversations, and blabing about solar panels. There are some birds in some of  these shots, but its incidental.  I recommend this movie for anyone who doesn't feel appreciative about how well made rom-coms are.

Only a movie this bad could have scenes like the one where the main character says "there's dead people on the side of the road!" then when he walks over to the bodies yells "they're dead!" There are so many shots that last a full 30 seconds after everyone stopped talking, so the actors are just standing there doing nothing. The sound editing is hilariously bad, the volume of everyone's voices changes often and there are awkward silences whenever the camera cuts to a new shot. The birds don't move much, they just have a looped animation of their wings moving up and down. The disease the birds have is, in a creative twist, called "bird flu virus." So bad it's funny, and so funny it hurts.

It takes a rare breed, say, a Tommy Wiseau, to bring us such a terrible and yet genuine film.  James Nguyen fills that role admirably...I mean, obviously the man has no business in directing films, and yet, at the same time, thank God he is!  

Look, there is a difference between terrible GOOD and terrible BAD.  Terrible bad is when you create a movie that is so vile that it lacks any universal appeal; nothing can be called "funny" about it, and you cannot pull enjoyment from any aspect of its production.  A good example?  Take anything starring Tom Green or directed by Eli Roth; both would be terrible films, but its not because of a lack of budget, or direction (per say) but they commit some Original Sin of being either vile, offensive, or unwatchable for whatever reason.

Terrible Good films are those that make an honest effort and just, well...fail; they are not intended to offend or play upon "shock" for the sake of itself...they are just laughable bad and, in some odd part of the mind for many, enjoyable in their badness.  Part of humor, after all, stems from the absurd, and films like Birdemic manage to fit that bill to a T!
Worst movie I've ever seen.  However,  I laughed so hard at how bad it was that I had tears streaming down. Great movie if you want to laugh at it's ridiculousness.

Birdemic is the work of a genuine artist.  Writer/director James Nguyen has made a film that embraces his love of HItchcock and environmental issues.  The only problem is that this artist has absolutely no talent.
This is the best movie i've ever seen
While it's not as "good" as "The Room", "Birdemic" is too entertainingly bad to truly hate. Which isn't to say it's good, of course.

This film is probably one of the best worst movies I've seen.  The fluctuating audio levels, the artistic decision to have no audio at all at times.  The first 45 minutes that in no way drive the story forward.  I like the nod to 70's movies with the 5 minute scene of the protagonist just driving to work and the traffic on his way.  The scene in a club with a singer on stage just singing remonded me of 70's movies too.  But most of all this is a movie with a simple message: solar power, hybrid cars, global warming is bad, use of fossil fuels, the war in Iraq is bad, and imaginepeace.com.  It's that single, seven messages you should take away with you after watching this.

Let's say you took Tommy Wiseau and bashed him in the head with a hammer a few times. Then you give him a handheld camera and a script that a retarded squirrel wrote with his penis. It is absolutely INCONCEIVABLE that he wouldn't be able to make a better movie than "Birdemic".
I love so bad its good, but this movie is on a completely different playing field than movies like Troll 2 or the Room. This movie is so bad its still bad.

Literally the worst film I have ever seen in every category.  The writer/director has absolutely NO grasp on anything that happens in reality and it is absolutely hilarious!  All the characters are written as though they have mental deficiencies and the acting is perhaps the worst I have ever seen, with a remarkably unremarkable performance by the atrocious and rigid lead, Alan Bagh.  The writing and special effects are horrendous but I am thankful they make me laugh.  Absolutely nothing in the script/film works and maybe that's what makes this so beautiful.

An absolute masterpiece. You have never seen anything like this before, I can guarantee it. Unbelievable in every sense of the word. I really don't know where to even start with it.

First, the acting is just amazing. Honestly, it makes the cast of 'Troll 2' look like Robert Redford, Dustin Hoffman and Daniel Day Lewis. Alan Bagh turns in what is without a doubt the best/worst performance of all time, and I say that with no reservations. Fortunately for everyone's enjoyment, every other cast member is equally horrific. An excellent twist of casting events is detailed on the back of the DVD, exclaiming 'Featuring a special appearance by Tippi Heddrin!!' I'm seriously not shitting you, this 'special appearance' is footage of her on the TV in the background of a scene. 

Another thing is, of course, the special effects. To call them 'special effects' is actually disrespectful to special effects, because in place of effects are GIFs. It is so unreal that it really makes you question the reality we live in. 

The direction and editing (particularly the sound editing) are other major points. It is simply a masterpiece of technical execution. The fact that this took Nguyen 4 years to produce this is mind-numbing. It seriously should have taken perhaps 4 weeks.

All of the horrible acting, execution and visual effects aside, the dialogue and story are what sell it. So may incredible moments... The dance scene at the bar, the boardroom scene, the hippie in the woods scene, the coat-hanger scene, and a plethora of others combine for a most memorable viewing experience. The ridiculously heavy handed message regarding global warming has done more harm than good for the cause I'm sure.

I feel like I've done a crappy job reviewing this film, but if I can impose one thing, just do yourself a favor and see it. There is no way I can properly put into perspective the incredible horrificness of this movie. It is simply incredible. Incredible. I can not wait for 'Birdemic 2' in motherfucking 3D.

Words cannot describe how awful Birdemic: Shock and Terror really is. It's something you need to witness for yourself. At least Troll 2 had some sort of production value - this movie features laughable acting, terrible special effects, shockingly horrible audio and only remnants of an actual story. It's only redeeming quality is how jaw-droppingly bad it is. Why didn't I watch this with Rifftrax? Why?
The single worst movie ever made.
Worse than "The Room" and yet somehow more enjoyable.
It's so bad. No matter how much they swat at those birds, they can't seem to hit them. Hm. It's almost as if they weren't there at all. But this movie is a blast to make fun of. I'll give it that.

I honestly can't say whether or not there's anything enjoyable about this movie, because the quality of it was so poor that I couldn't sit through more than five minutes of it. It looks as though it was filmed on someone's decrepit handheld camcorder, and the sound is about at the same level. The acting is completely nonexistent, and I'm pretty sure the director just hired a bunch of morons on the street without knowing if they could actually act to begin with. Do not waste your time.

I have seen a lot of movies, and I really think this is the worst I have ever seen.  Yes, I've seen "Manos:  The Hands of Fate," I've seen "The Room," but those movies are so bad they are fun to laugh at.  This movie is just painful!  The script makes no sense, the special effects would have been better if made by 1st graders with crayons, and the acting!  Ugh!  Can you even call it acting?  Alan Bagh, where did they find him?  He can't even walk naturally!  Nothing is convincing with him, and he mumbles!  Also, he (and other actors) flub lines at times!  Why weren't they reshot?  This movie is just a complete mess!

Do you expect quality from a movie called Birdemic?  The acting is more wooden then wood, the effects are bafflingly bad, the sound editing is the worst in any thing ever, pointless shots are dragged on, and the plots ridiculous.  This movie is so bad it's good.  This is honestly one of the most unintentionally funny movies ever made.  No human being can which this with a straight face.  I could not possibly imagine what anyone apart of this movie was thinking.  The easiest way to describe this movie is Ferngully meets Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds.  This is something Ed Wood would make.  Actually watching the behind the scenes stuff is just as hilarious as the movie considering how insane the director is.  This movie is great for a good laugh.  The best way to know this movie is to watch it. It has to be seen to be believed.

Ow........ I mean, OWWWWWWW! I've sat through some terrible things in my lifetime (Most of the time intentionally for some "so bad it's good" action), and this....... this is worse than After Last Season, and considering I could do nothing but talk like a chocobo for a day after seeing that, that's....... a feat.

The thing to Birdemic is all of its amateurishness is extremely tedious. The cheap opening credits drag on and on in that Manos kind of way, the first 45 minutes are excruciatingly with endless driving to places, terrible sound, and courtship scenes so bland, it's like they took the two most boring profiles off a dating website and made a movie about them. Then the shock and terror appears and you can only laugh so much at the same awful green screen trick implemented over and over and over, and the money shots of hilarious badness are few and far between (There's a reason the clothes hanger scene and the ".....THEY GOT BECKY!" moment get constant replay. There's not a lot else). It just doesn't have the insanity to get to the Ed Wood realm. It's just plain terrible.

Dumb. Shit. and all its synonyms. Normally, I life these movies but this was just unbearable. Biggest pet peeve: riddling your film with political causes. Even if I agree, I don't want to hear about it, I ant to watch a movie!
Beyond horrible, but the Rifftrax makes it fucking hilarious. I'd give Mike, Kevin, and Bill's commentary a 5/5 if I could. Haven't laughed that hard at a movie in ages.

This is really 2 movies.  One side is a clunky romantic comedy and the other is The Birds.  It is hilarious in all honest.  The romantic comedy part is long, drawn-out and boring, but it is far worth it for the terrible effects and acting of the second part.  I recommend this movie to fans of bad movies.  It is seriously so bad it is funny.

I'm not going to talk about the birds or the editing or the acting here. I don't really care about that stuff in a movie. It's the writing that matters to me. And with Birdemis I felt like it was the writing that confused me the most.
First of all, I don't know if this movie was being serious. There is no way anyone could have thought that this movie would serve as a warning to anyone about global warming. I get the distinct impression that this entire production is a joke meant to satirize environmentalists. If this thing is serious, then I can imagine anyone who agrees with its "message" just being embarrassed at the movies ham-handedness. Either way, this movie is childishly incoherent. It fails in every way possible. 
This thing is second only to "Actium Maximus" on my list of worst movies of all time.
So bad!  It's not even the good bad.

Laughing at this movie is like laughing at the mentally handicapped... because every single person involved with this HAS to be at least a little incapacitated.

Seriously, how could no one at any point from pre through post-production stop and say, "gee, this movie is gonna be fucking awful and should probably never see the light of day lest the world entire think us incompetent."

Un.Be.Lievable.
everyone watch this now

Imagine if you will a commercial for a small local business pops on the tv; it's painfully cheap in the sense the actors are not actors, just friends or family of said small business owners, who simply just state their lines almost as if they are unable to emote at all; the director and editor have never directed or edited in their lives and just cut and paste film together without taking things such as audio quality and lighting into consideration. Now imagine, if you still have any desire to, that an entire film was made this way, for under $10,000 and most of THAT money went to marketing the film. That should give you a pretty good idea of how Birdemic: Shock and Terror looks and feels.

That being said, it's incredibly painful to watch, yet somehow you find yourself being a glutton for punishment; begging to see if it can possibly get worse and boy does it.

The first 5 minutes of the film is the main character driving his car through the country side. Did I mention 5 minutes? Yes, it takes that long for anything else to happen. In this scene he doesn't talk to anyone, doesn't rock out to a song on the radio. He simply stares forward and drives and we get a few different angles of the car as it slowly cruises along.

Thus goes for nearly every scene in the film; it goes on way too long and is thus made unbearably awkward. In one such awkward scene, where I quite literally rolled around on the floor laughing, our hero and his super model girlfriend dance at a seemingly empty Irish bar. Empty aside from a lone black man on stage singing some sort of disco song about "getting down, getting down with my family, having ourselves a party!" They do stereotypical "white people" dance moves for the WHOLE length of the song, all the while said black man's lips rarely sync up with the lyrics.

Perhaps what got me the most is there is no hint at all about killer birds until 50 minutes into the film and, when they are introduced into the film... well, let's just say you've seen better CGI in 1993.

I honestly thoroughly enjoyed how insanely bad this movie was. My only real complaint is how drawn out the movie gets after the killer birds come into play; it's almost the same scene over and over again and some of the stupid charm gets lost along the way. That and the ending is mind bogglingly lame.

Really stoked to see what James Nguyen brings to the table later this year with Birdemic 2: Resurrection 3D. Yes, that is the actual title.

absolutely 100% of everything in this movie made it the worst widely released feature film of all time. which is why in my eyes, its one of the best and it only made it better that it wasnt supposed to be just completely god fucking awful, and was supposed to be taken seriously. cant wait for the sequel this year.

Didn't really generate the kind of laugh-out-loud response I got when seeing The Room, Birdemic manages to be much, much worse. It doesn't really result in a better movie though. 

The final portion sort of drags but when's it on, it's pretty fucking amazing. The sound editing is priceless and the build to the CGI birds (who look like animated .gifs of those zombie crows on the PS1 Resident Evil games) is genuinely terrific. Maybe this'll click even more when I'm drunk or something

This is the worst movie I've ever seen in my life.  Everything from acting to writing to sound and lighting...I've never seen a movie so thoroughly awful.  It doesn't even make sense, and I'm talking major plot points and the basic reasoning of the characters, etc.  It gets one star from me for the unbelievable entertainment value as a fun bad movie.  Great to watch with friends and laugh over.  And I really love the birds!  And why are these people just driving, and driving, and driving around?  Where are they going??

Wow.. This is absolutely the WORST movie I've ever seen.  Nothing redeeming about this movie. Just when you think it can't get any worse, it does!  Terrible acting, HORRIBLE special effects!  With that said, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND you watch this flick just for the sake of saying you sat through the worst movie ever made.. Oh yea, and a sequel is coming out for this piece of shit later this year.
The one noise they use for the birds still haunts me.

This is the best movie I have ever watched. The beautiful, mind blowing graphics and the fluid bird animation, combined with great actors, well thought out plot and a great script makes a huge mark on the filming industry and is well known to be a genius creation. Go watch it now!

Say what you will about a movie like Birdemic but here is one thing that is undeniable: THIS IS ENTERTAINING. Everything is so laughably bad that you have to watch it over and over like a car wreck. I can't fathom watching a Michael Bay movie multiple times and yet I can watch Birdemic a dozen times and come away giggling.
This movie is so generic. I absolutely hated it. It's boring, the birds aren't even real looking. It's soooooooooo stupid. The actors can't act.. Wasn't worth a penny, let alone a dollar..
Has to been seen by RIffTrax. Everything is bad in this movie. All they do in this movie is drive and park. The Twilight movies are better than this.

So bad it's good. At first glance one might wonder if it was made to be a serious environmental message, however, between the awful editing, acting and effects there's no question about it. Birdemic is a parody of Al Gore's worst nightmare. So if it's such a blazingly craptastic example of cinematic ineptitude, why in the hell am I giving it 3 stars? It's on the basis that Birdemic is probably the best comedy to come along in decades. Oh yes, it's right up there with Tommy Wiseau's cinematic opus, "The Room". But this one displays even more 
hilarious examples of failing when it tries to take itself seriously at all. In a world(meaning ours) where comedies these days are about as funny as dying children in Africa, Birdemic is a movie that will truly make you forget your worries and make you laugh through it's odd attempts at a serious sci-fi movie.
Terrible.....and amazing!!!!!

Birdemic is a beautiful, moving masterpiece of cinema. I've never seen so much romance, shock, and terror on the screen at once. James Nguyen is a innovator of cinema and can be compared to great directors such as Hitchcock, and Kubrick. The movie might go on to be one of the best of all time. If you haven't seen Birdemic you need to change that very soon.

Do not be deceived by my rating. This is a terrible, terrible movie. It definitely dips into the "so bad its hilarious" category. But for what it lacks in actual proficient skill it totally makes up for in ROFLs. So five-star entertainment with zero-star production value/creativity/or anything. It does everything wrong from the choppy audio to the stilted acting to the hilarious pro-Gore agenda. I couldn't decide if the director was in on the joke or not. So yeah, not a good movie... but if you're looking for a good time with a terrible movie, this is a pretty good option.

This film is incredible! It is so horrible that you have to love it. Never in my life have i seen something so breathtakingly horrible yet so entertaining at the same time. I am still stunned by this movie's lack of heart, soul, or wit. And I loved every second of it. This is as bad a movie as you can find, so bad, that you will enjoy it to the end of your days.
FUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUCK! Watching it Rifftraxed is a must.

One of those movies that fails on every level so hard, it is as spectacular to watch as a head collision between to oncoming trains. Move over Tommy Wiseau, James Nguyen has dragged cinema to new, hilarious low.

Some of the worst CG birds ever put to video. Terrible acting, plot, dialogue, and just about everything else. However, it's the kind of bad movie where someone must have been in on the joke and it is entertaining in its badness at times.
Largely, this film functions as a guide for how to respectfully court someone and initiate a relationship. There are also some crazed, exploding eagles.
The best worst movie ever made.

Intentionally really really bad. The script felt like it was written by a jr. high student and the acting out of this screenplay felt like it was done in the first shooting and no re-takes. Also, the CGI here of the birds felt like it was copied and pasted from a .gif file offline. A lot of this makes the film quite hilarious and makes it stand out as one of the best-worst films of all time. I can't see how someone couldn't laugh at how bad it is, and apparently there is a planned sequel in 3D, which I am looking forward to. The only real 'compliaint' I have with this film is that they could have made it a lot more laughable and lot less boring in a lot of acts here. Some scenes do really drag, but other than that, I couldn't help but laugh at this intentional mess of a film. People who trash this film must have no clue that this is supposed to be the way it is. This is a good film to bring to a party to have some good laughs.

               Yes, take a great big look at the rating I have assigned to "Birdemic: Shock and Terror". It's been called one of the worst films ever made by others, and they're not kidding. However, "Birdemic" is also the biggest laugh you're likely to have since you saw "The Room", that is, if you saw "The Room".

         Being a horror fan, I can't help but be insulted by this flick. It's stupid, lame, and is helmed by a man who attempts many things and possesses only one thing: the ability to get everything- and I mean everything- wrong. Seldom do we see films as bad as this one, but then again, seldom do we see films as funny as this one either. It could either be the funniest night at the movies or the most tedious. Me, I think it's kind of a mixture. This film blows big time, but it's funny-as-hell, and I will buy it, watch it many times over with friends, and someday even participate in the little cult it has garnered. In all its crap-tacular glory, "Birdemic" kind of deserves every bit of criticism, hate, and toilet-paper that it coming its way. But it also deserves some recognition for being so-bad-it's-good. It's the new king of that section of cinema, without a doubt.
            
             Here's a story that attempts many things. The first thing you will notice is that the movie itself is about birds attacking and killing people. Hitchcock did that when he made "The Birds". That film was smart, and now we get this film, which is "The Birds" for dummies. No, make that complete dumbasses. And yes, I'm kind of a dumbass for enjoying it so much, but we all have our guilty pleasures. This is one of mine.
         
          Aside from the bird invasion, there are sub-plots involving the hero's work life, his love life, his social life, and whatnot. All attempted; all fail. But at least the failure is fun to watch.
           
        Were they serious when they conceived this? Did they really think that birds which explode when they're shot, shit acid, and hover over people's heads would scare people? Something tells me that they were serious, because they have made a really, REALLY crappy movie here. If you like those kinds of movies, then this is one to see. I'd recommend it to just about any cinephile, for despite its overbearing crapiness, it deserves to be seen. It's unoriginal, pathetic, and stupid to the point where I couldn't stop laughing. It's probably the most enjoyable film not intent on being enjoyable.

          So where do these laughs come from, you ask. They come from many sources. First off, the concept is funny, and it always will be. Birds attacking people can either be scary and intelligent or silly and quite funny. Here, it's funny-as-hell. I laughed my ass off; I really did. The birds are some of the worst looking I've seen in years. The CGI is so simple, the movements are off, and all the stupid buzzards do is hover over people (and their cars). Surprisingly, this can kill them. Way to leave it all to the imagination, guys. Way to go. Also, the acting is painfully bad, and so is the plotting. Another thing that makes "Birdemic" so god-awful is the sound editing. Let me just tell you something: this is some of the worst sound editing I've ever heard. You kind of chuckle whenever you hear it; but how could you not?
 
       Look, people. I hate this movie as much as anyone else does. It's one of the worst films ever made, and its completely unaware of it. But in a world where few actual COMEDIES can serve up laughs, "Birdemic" delivers them by doing its job wrong, on all ends. I appreciate the film for its horrible ideas, horrible direction, and non-stop hilarity; and detest it, at the same time, for its flaws. But I'm glad I saw it; everyone should be. Just go in knowing that this thing is stupid. However, also go in knowing that you are going to laugh. And that explains why I gave "Birdemic" the rating that I have given it.

Why "Shock and Terror"? Why not "Birdemic: Shock and Caw"? Man, this movie's so bad, why not go with the corny title? What the movie fails to realize is that even not trying requires some effort if you're gonna make an intentionally bad movie, if that is, in fact, their intention. Otherwise, you get a poor quality waste like "Birdemic: Sock and Terror", which I would say leans more towards the amateur film category than independent film category were it not for the fact that I would be insulting amateur filmmakers. The movie suffers from overdevelopment, dragging, poor sound quality, choppy storyline editing, impossibly awful footage editing, a bad soundtrack with poor placement, cliches, awe-inspiringly atrocious visual effects, terrible writing, unbelievable character behavior, a forced resolution, a cop-out ending and acting that left me waiting for the big art house, not-so-happy ending where our heroes are finally slaine by a surprise swarm of woodpeckers. Really, all I can say about "Birdemic: Shock and Terror" is that it is of such poor quality that it's offensive to the art of filmmaking and those who put effort into it.
It's... unforgettable. And technically, even I could do better than that.

This might well be the worst edited, most clumsilly written and terribly shot movie I've ever seen. Oh yeah, and it also has what is probably the worst special effects in cinema history. If it had been intentional, a goofy comedy, it might have been interesting, but as of now it is just amazingly bad. To add to it, Birdemic is one of those movies that are not satisfied having their environmentalist message in your face but go for cramming it up your nose. While I'm not dismissing the debate on global warming, I have yet to see proof that it gives eagles acid urine and makes them explode on impact.

What do you say about Birdemic that hasn't already been said? This movie is currently in the running for worst movie ever made, and the internet has pit it against heavy weights like The Room and Troll 2. 

But honestly I think Birdemic seizes it for me. I don't know if it's just the animated GIF birds that movie when the camera does. The "acting" that is just about the worse thing you've ever experienced, it might be the editing which seems to have been done by a child and gives us a multitude of shots that linger for too long giving us a glimpse of the performers as they sit and comtemplate the rubbish they've just spouted. Or how EVERY time someone has to walk to their cars we have to see the entire journey from door to door.

All of these factors definitely contribute but I think what really does it for me is the films heavy handed environmental message. Delivered by a bunch of random encounters with strange hippes talking about their tree boners directly into the camera in lengthy monologues that make great bathroom breaks. Honestly, you owe it to yourself to experience this.

When you go into Birdemic, the overall pleasure of the experience depends on the perspective you have. If you go into this movie expecting nothing more than cheesy effects, poor acting, and just a laughable plot, then this movie is really funny. However, if you're expecting a legitamate horror/thriller film similar to Alfred Hitchcock's "The Birds", then look elsewhere. Birdemic: Shock And Terror is either the funniest comedy of 2009, or the worst thriller of 2009.

Birdemic stars Rod, a software salesman and his model girlfriend Natalie. For the first half of the film, the mostly just do stuff. Nothing of lasting importance, we just see what bland people do on a daily basis, mainly consisting of awkward conversations with family members and getting too excited or under excited about daily events. After the awkward couple gets close (I guess), the birds finally attack the town. And yes, these birds explode. Because, you know, that makes them SO much cooler! Somehow, the two main characters survive the bird attacks as well as two kids they save and as the film ends they watch the birds fly away, never to return again.

This film fails on all levels. The plot and story could basically be summed up in one statement: STOP POLLUTING THE ENVIROMENT OR RABID BIRDS THAT CAN EXPLODE AND SPIT ACID PUKE WILL ATTACK YOU! The characters are as wooden as wooden can be. And, did I mention, THE BIRDS FRIGGIN EXPLODE! And unfortunately, the explosions don't follow the rules of science and nature. Tell me if it's possible and I'll retract the statement, but isn't it impossible for an "exploding" bird to explode in a gas station and not set the whole place in flames? The special effects are mind bogglingly bad with clip art birds and overused sound clips that'll melt your brain. The editing is some of the worst I've seen in years, with unnecessary cutaways and poor sound editing.

What makes me laugh is that the director actually can take this as a serious romantic/thriller film. What a smug dude. Anyways, if you want some Ed Wood style laughs, go check out Birdemic: Shock And Terror. For the rest of us, just avoid this movie and rewatch "The Birds". (Real rating: 9%)
